tool_input.content:
# Literature Review: Diagnostic Methods for Distinguishing AGN from Star-Forming Galaxies Using Multi-Wavelength Data

## Overview

The classification of active galactic nuclei (AGN) versus star-forming galaxies is a fundamental challenge in extragalactic astronomy, particularly as surveys expand to higher redshifts and fainter luminosities. A comprehensive suite of diagnostic techniques has been developed over the past 40+ years, spanning optical emission-line spectroscopy, infrared photometry and spectroscopy, X-ray observations, and radio detection. These methods exploit the distinct physical ionization mechanisms, dust properties, and energy generation processes that distinguish AGN-powered systems from starburst galaxies. This review synthesizes current diagnostic methodologies and highlights persistent challenges in classification, particularly regarding composite systems and host-galaxy contamination.

---

## 1. Optical Emission-Line Diagnostics (BPT Diagrams)

### Foundational Work

**Baldwin, Phillips & Terlevich (1981) – Pioneering Diagnostic Framework**
- **Citation**: Baldwin, Phillips & Terlevich (BPT), 1981
- **Problem**: Initial classification of ionization sources in nebular emission-line galaxies
- **Methodology**: Developed the first emission-line ratio diagrams using diagnostic line pairs:
  - Primary: [NII]λ6584/Hα vs. [OIII]λ5007/Hβ (BPT-NII diagram)
  - Secondary: [SII]λ6717,6731/Hα vs. [OIII]λ5007/Hβ (VO87-SII diagram)
  - Tertiary: [OI]λ6300/Hα vs. [OIII]λ5007/Hβ (VO87-OI diagram)
- **Key Result**: Distinct regions for star-forming galaxies, composite AGN-HII systems, Seyfert 2 nuclei, and LINERs
- **Advantages**: Robust at low redshift (z < 0.3), requires only optical spectroscopy
- **Limitations**: Sensitive to dust attenuation in Balmer lines, requires rest-frame optical coverage at z > 0.4, affected by temperature and density effects in ionized gas

---

### Modern Demarcation Lines

**Kewley et al. (2001, 2006) – Empirical Classification Scheme**
- **Citation**: Kewley, Dopita, Sutherland, et al. 2001; Kewley et al. 2006
- **Dataset**: 85,224 emission-line galaxies from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS)
- **Methodology**: Derived new empirical and theoretical demarcation lines separating:
  - Pure star-forming galaxies (below composite boundary)
  - Composite AGN-HII systems (between two boundaries)
  - Seyfert 2 nuclei (above AGN boundary)
  - LINERs (region above and to the left)
- **Key Equations** (Kewley et al. 2006 empirical line):
  - log([OIII]/Hβ) = 0.61 / (log([NII]/Hα) - 0.05) + 1.3 (star-forming upper bound)
  - log([OIII]/Hβ) = 0.72 / (log([NII]/Hα) - 0.37) + 1.19 (AGN lower bound)
- **Key Result**: Clean separation of galaxy classes with well-defined AGN and star-forming regions
- **Quantitative Performance**: >90% classification accuracy for unambiguous sources
- **Limitations**:
  - Contamination rate of ~37% in composite region (significant misclassification)
  - Star-forming galaxies classified as AGN: ~16.2% misclassification rate
  - Performance degraded at high-z due to reduced emission-line equivalent widths and dust attenuation

---

### Near-Infrared Emission-Line Diagnostics

**Near-Infrared AGN Diagnostics (Local Universe to z~3)**
- **Citation**: Recent work extending diagnostics to NIR (Ager et al. 2023)
- **Methodology**: Developed new diagnostic diagrams using NIR forbidden and permitted lines:
  - NIR-based diagnostics using [FeII], [CaII], Paschen series lines
  - Accessible to z~3 with modern ground-based NIR spectroscopy
  - Advantage: Less affected by dust attenuation than optical lines
- **Key Result**: Successful separation of AGN from star-forming galaxies in NIR
- **Advantages**:
  - Reduced dust extinction effects (NIR vs. optical)
  - Extended redshift applicability
  - Coronal lines ([Ne V], [Mg VII]) excellent AGN indicators
- **Limitations**: Requires high signal-to-noise NIR spectroscopy; coronal line detection challenging in lower-luminosity systems

---

## 2. Mid-Infrared Color-Color Diagnostics

### WISE Color Selection Criteria

**WISE Infrared Selection Framework**
- **Citation**: Assef et al. (2010, 2013); multiple subsequent applications
- **Dataset**: All-sky WISE survey (339 million sources); detailed validation in COSMOS, NDWFS Boötes fields
- **Key Diagnostic Criterion**:
  - **Simple demarcation**: W1 − W2 ≥ 0.8 (robust AGN selection)
  - **Alternative**: W1 − W2 ≥ 0.7 (higher completeness, lower reliability)
  - **Earlier proposals**: W1 − W2 ≥ 0.5 (Ashby et al. 2009); W1 − W2 ≥ 0.85 (Assef et al. 2010)

**Assef et al. (2013) – NDWFS Boötes Field Study**
- **Problem Statement**: Determine optimal WISE color cuts for AGN selection; validate completeness and reliability trade-offs
- **Methodology**:
  - Multi-wavelength SED analysis from UV to mid-IR
  - Cross-matched with optical spectroscopy for ground truth
  - Analyzed color reliability as function of W2 magnitude
- **Key Results**:
  - W1 − W2 ≥ 0.8 achieves 90% reliability for W2 < 15.05
  - Color-magnitude cut (W1 − W2 dependent on W2 magnitude) maintains 90% reliability to W2 < 17.11
  - Identified 130 ± 4 deg−2 AGN candidates with 90% reliability
  - 95% of reliable AGN candidates have AGN dominating bolometric output
  - Successfully selects both obscured and unobscured AGN
- **Limitations**:
  - Biased toward AGN-dominated systems (misses weak AGN hosts)
  - Performance degrades at faint fluxes (W2 > 17)
  - High-redshift (z > 2−3) star-forming galaxies can occupy AGN color space

---

### Advanced WISE Diagnostics

**Two-Dimensional WISE Color-Color Diagnostics**
- **Mateos et al. (2012) and subsequent work**
- **Methodology**:
  - W1 − W2 vs. W2 − W3 color-color diagram
  - Defines AGN selection wedge in upper-right corner
  - Specific analytical equations for demarcation boundaries
- **Key Advantages**:
  - Reduces contamination from star-forming galaxies
  - Identifies intermediate-luminosity AGN not selected by W1−W2 alone
  - Incorporates longer-wavelength WISE information
- **Quantitative Results**: Improved purity and completeness relative to single-color cuts
- **Limitations**: W3 and W4 bands at 12 and 22 μm affected by star-formation dust emission; less sensitive for obscured AGN

---

### Spitzer Mid-Infrared Spectroscopy

**Mid-Infrared Spectral Features for AGN Diagnostics**
- **Citation**: Spitzer IRS observations; multiple studies 2008-present
- **Key Diagnostic Features**:
  - **PAH feature strength**: Strong 7.7 and 11.3 μm PAH features indicate star formation; weak PAH features with hot dust continuum indicate AGN
  - **Silicate absorption at 9.7 μm**: Indicates dust column density; obscured AGN show strong absorption
  - **Emission lines**: [Ne II] 12.8 μm, [Ne III] 15.6 μm, [S III] 18.7 μm distinguish ionization source
  - **Power-law continuum**: Characteristic of hot dust around AGN accretion
- **Quantitative Diagnostic**:
  - F(6.2μm PAH) / F(continuum) ratio separates AGN-dominated from SF-dominated systems
  - Ionized line ratios ([Ne III]/[Ne II] or [S IV]/[S III]) indicate ionization hardness
- **Advantages**:
  - Selects both unobscured and heavily obscured AGN
  - Less affected by dust extinction than optical/UV
  - Aperture < few kpc sensitive to nuclear AGN
- **Limitations**:
  - Extended star-formation contribution significant at longer wavelengths (> 15 μm)
  - Requires spectroscopic observations (limited sample sizes vs. photometry)
  - Weak AGN hosts difficult to distinguish from pure starbursts

---

## 3. X-Ray and Multi-Wavelength SED Fitting

### X-Ray Detection and Identification

**X-Ray as AGN Diagnostic**
- **Fundamental Principle**: AGN emit hard X-rays (> 2 keV) via Compton scattering in hot coronae; star-forming galaxies produce soft X-rays via hot stellar populations and supernovae
- **Key Advantage**: X-rays penetrate dust; detects heavily obscured AGN invisible in optical
- **Quantitative Detection**:
  - Unobscured AGN: 0.2−10 keV luminosity ~10^42-44 erg/s for typical systems
  - Hard X-ray excess (> 2 keV) distinguishes AGN from starburst
- **Challenges**: Low signal-to-noise for faint sources; requires pointing observations (limited all-sky coverage)

---

### X-Ray to Infrared Flux Ratios

**Multiwavelength Flux Ratio Diagnostics**
- **Key Insight**: Ratio of X-ray to infrared flux encodes AGN accretion-power vs. thermal reprocessing through dust torus
- **Diagnostic Method**:
  - High X-ray luminosity (L_X) relative to infrared luminosity (L_IR) indicates unobscured AGN
  - Low L_X/L_IR ratio indicates obscured AGN or composite systems
- **SED Modeling Approach**:
  - X-CIGALE (X-ray CIGALE) code fits radio-to-X-ray SEDs
  - Incorporates dust torus geometry, AGN accretion disk, and host galaxy components
  - X-ray flux helps break degeneracy between AGN and host galaxy in UV
- **Results**:
  - X-CIGALE AGN luminosities show close agreement with X-ray selected AGN
  - Constrains AGN bolometric luminosity
  - Can identify AGN contributing > 10% of galaxy mid-IR luminosity

---

### SED Fitting Methodologies

**DEVILS Survey – Deep Extragalactic Visible Legacy Survey (Thorne et al. 2022)**
- **Dataset**: 217,000 galaxies with optical spectroscopy
- **Methodology**: ProSpect SED fitting code incorporating:
  - Stellar population synthesis models
  - Dust attenuation
  - AGN accretion-powered emission (torus and accretion disk)
- **Key Results**:
  - Identified AGN in ~8% of sample
  - AGN bolometric luminosity function calibrated
  - Improved host-galaxy property constraints with AGN components
- **Quantitative Output**:
  - AGN fraction increases with galaxy stellar mass
  - Torus emission contribution ranges from 1−100% of total
- **Limitations**: Requires high-quality multi-wavelength photometry (UV to 24 μm); SED degeneracies for low-luminosity AGN

---

**Hot Dust in Panchromatic SED Fitting (2018 study)**
- **Problem**: Failure to account for hot AGN dust in SED fits biases galaxy parameters
- **Methodology**:
  - Include hot dust (T ~ 1200 K) component in SED templates
  - Dust-temperature-dependent modeling
  - Validated against 47 galaxies with high-quality Spitzer spectroscopy
- **Quantitative Impact**:
  - Omitting AGN component: systematic overestimate of stellar mass by up to 150%
  - SFR overestimate by up to 300%
  - Dust attenuation underestimate by factor of 2.5
  - AGN present in ~10% of typical galaxy surveys at > 10% contribution to MIR
- **Performance**: Improved predictions for Hα, Hβ, Spitzer/IRS spectra when including AGN
- **Limitation**: Requires spectroscopic validation for reliable AGN identification

---

## 4. Machine Learning and Statistical Classification Methods

### Early Machine Learning Applications

**Photometric Classification of Emission-Line Galaxies (2013)**
- **Citation**: Machine learning methods for photometric AGN classification
- **Methodology**:
  - Support Vector Machines (SVMs)
  - Random Forests
  - Applied to multi-band photometric data
- **Dataset**: SDSS + multi-wavelength ancillary data
- **Challenge Identified**: High contamination near classification boundaries (e.g., near Heckman line); ML methods sensitive to training data quality

---

### Recent Machine Learning Advances

**Multi-band AGN-SFG Classifier for Radio Surveys (2023)**
- **Citation**: Recent work using machine learning for radio-survey AGN classification
- **Methodology**:
  - Light Gradient Boosting Machines (LGBM)
  - Multi-wavelength feature inputs (radio, infrared, optical)
  - Applied to modern surveys with extensive training data
- **Performance Metrics**:
  - AGN precision: 0.974, recall: 0.865
  - Ability to identify weak AGN hosts
  - Reduced contamination vs. color-cut methods
- **Key Advantage**: Captures non-linear feature interactions across wavelengths
- **Limitation**: Requires unambiguous training dataset; performance degrades in regions of ambiguous optical diagnostics

---

**Identifying Radio AGN with Machine Learning (2024-2025)**
- **Citation**: Identifying Radio Active Galactic Nuclei with Machine Learning and Large-Area Surveys (2025)
- **Dataset**: Large-area radio surveys (LOFAR, VLA)
- **Methodology**:
  - Neural networks and ensemble methods
  - Multi-wavelength cross-matching (radio, infrared, X-ray)
  - Self-organizing maps (SOMs) for unsupervised exploration
- **Key Results**:
  - Precision and recall for AGN samples: 94.2% and 92.3% respectively
  - SOMs useful for detecting compositional gradients
  - Manifold learning refines low-mass AGN detection
- **Advantages**: Scalable to large surveys; captures complex feature patterns
- **Challenges**: Requires high-quality cross-matched catalogs; training set bias affects performance

---

**Dwarf Galaxy AGN Detection with Unsupervised ML**
- **Citation**: Selection of Dwarf Galaxies Hosting AGN (2025)
- **Methodology**:
  - Unsupervised machine learning (k-means, hierarchical clustering)
  - Multi-band photometry + optical spectroscopy
  - Bias and contamination quantification
- **Key Result**: Successfully identifies low-luminosity AGN in dwarf galaxies where optical diagnostics fail
- **Challenge**: Minimal training data for dwarf AGN; high false-positive rate without spectroscopic validation

---

**Photometric AGN Identification - Machine Learning with SDSS**
- **Citation**: Identifying galaxies, quasars, and stars with machine learning; 111 million SDSS sources
- **Methodology**:
  - Deep learning and ensemble methods
  - Pure photometric classification (no spectra)
  - Feature importance analysis
- **Performance**:
  - Overall classification accuracy > 99% for galaxy/quasar separation
  - AGN subclass precision varies (80-95% depending on luminosity)
- **Limitation**: Photometric-only classification suffers from AGN/galaxy degeneracies; requires multi-band photometry

---

## 5. Composite Systems and Contamination Challenges

### Contamination Quantification

**Diagnostic-Diagram Contamination Rates**
- **Problem Statement**: Galaxies classified as composites in one diagnostic may be pure AGN or star-forming in another; misclassification rates quantify this contamination
- **Quantitative Contamination Rates** (from recent literature):
  - **Composite region contamination**: Only 40% classified as composite are true composites; 57% are composites by reference classification; **global contamination rate ~37%**
  - **AGN region**: Only 37% of objects actually AGN; 18% star-forming galaxies (misclassified); 45% true composites
  - **Star-forming region**: 16.2% of apparently star-forming galaxies classified as AGN by spectroscopy
  - **Overall misclassification**: Affects ~40-50% of sources in intermediate regions

---

### Physical Sources of Contamination

**Host Galaxy Dilution**
- **Mechanism**: Stellar continuum and star-formation emission from host galaxy dilutes nuclear AGN signatures in optical diagnostics
- **Redshift Dependence**: Effect amplifies at higher redshift where galaxy starlight dominates nuclear emission
- **Quantitative Effect**:
  - Transitional/composite classification increases with redshift
  - SFR amplifies host-galaxy dilution effect
  - Results in systematic shift toward lower line-ratio values
- **Implication**: Pure AGN optical signatures increasingly obscured at z > 0.5

---

**Starburst-AGN Composites**
- **Definition**: Galaxies with simultaneous intense star formation and accreting SMBHs
- **Diagnostic Challenge**:
  - Both processes produce ionization; optical line ratios overlap in intermediate regions
  - Cannot be cleanly separated by position in BPT diagram alone
  - Require multi-wavelength constraints (X-ray, radio, IR) to disentangle
- **Frequency**: Common in merger-driven systems; likely 30-40% of high-z star-forming galaxies

---

### Strategies to Mitigate Contamination

**Multi-Diagnostic Approach**
- **Methodology**: Combine optical, infrared, X-ray, and radio diagnostics to increase classification robustness
- **Example Approach**:
  - Primary classifier: BPT diagram (optical emission lines)
  - Confirmation: WISE W1-W2 color (mid-IR)
  - Refinement: X-ray detection (hard X-rays for unobscured AGN) or radio detection
  - High-z validation: SED fitting incorporating multi-wavelength constraints
- **Quantitative Improvement**: Multi-diagnostic approach reduces misclassification by 50-70% vs. single-diagnostic

---

**Machine Learning with Spectroscopic Ground Truth**
- **Methodology**: Train models on unambiguous spectroscopic samples; apply to ambiguous photometric samples
- **Key Requirement**: "Unambiguous training dataset is required to successfully train and apply any classification method"
- **Quantitative Result**: LGBM classifiers achieve > 90% accuracy on validation sets with diverse multi-wavelength data

---

**Narrow-Band and Intermediate-Band Photometry**
- **Advantage**: Filter sensitivity to emission lines ([OIII], Hα, Hβ) improves AGN/SF separation
- **Methodology**: 30+ photometric bands vs. standard broadband
- **Quantitative Benefit**: Significantly reduced photo-z outliers and AGN/host-galaxy degeneracies
- **Application**: PAU Survey, ALHAMBRA survey demonstrate effectiveness for photo-z and AGN classification

---

## 6. Radio Detection and Identification

### Radio-Excess AGN Methodology

**Radio-Excess Definition**
- **Principle**: Compare observed radio flux to star-formation-rate-related radio (FIR-radio relation)
- **Criterion**: Radio excess = (Observed L_radio) / (Expected L_radio from SFR)
- **AGN Detection Threshold**: Excess > 1.5-2.0σ indicates radio-AGN
- **Advantage**: Unaffected by dust extinction; detects low-luminosity radio-loud AGN

---

### Radio AGN vs. Star-Forming Galaxy Populations

**Distribution in Galaxy Populations (Recent Survey Results)**
- **Key Finding**: Radio AGN occupy distinct host-galaxy populations from X-ray selected AGN
  - Radio AGN: 87% in quiescent galaxies; 13% in star-forming galaxies
  - X-ray AGN: 62% in star-forming galaxies; 38% in quiescent galaxies
- **Redshift Evolution**:
  - z < 1: Radio-excess AGN dominated by quiescent galaxy hosts
  - 0 < z < 1.5: Star-forming radio AGN comparable density to quiescent
  - z > 1.5: Star-forming radio AGN dominate radio-excess population
- **Space Density Evolution**: Radio AGN space density in quiescent galaxies decreases toward higher redshift; inverse trend for star-forming hosts

---

### Challenges in Radio AGN Identification

**Ambiguous Radio Emission Sources**
- **Problem**: Weak radio detections can arise from either radio-mode AGN, relativistic jets, or intense star formation
- **Physical Confusion**:
  - Gigahertz-detected star-forming galaxies show enhanced ionized gas emission lines
  - Higher central outflow fractions suggest AGN activity
  - Redder colors and increased central obscuration (offset line ratios toward AGN regime)
- **Quantitative Uncertainty**: 20-30% of faint radio sources remain ambiguous AGN vs. starburst designation
- **Recent Finding**: Connection between radio emission and restarted/relic AGN activity complicates classification

---

## 7. Recent Developments and Emerging Diagnostics

### UV Emission-Line Diagnostics

**UV Lines for AGN Identification**
- **Key Lines**: He II λ1640, C IV λ1549, C III] λ1909
- **Diagnostic**: C III]/He II vs. C IV/He II line-ratio diagram
- **Advantage**: Accessible in UV spectra; separates AGN from star formation via ionization hardness
- **Application**: Useful for quiescent galaxies where optical emission lines weak; enables AGN detection in z > 1 systems with HST spectroscopy
- **Limitation**: Requires UV-sensitive spectroscopy; affected by stellar winds in young populations

---

### New Optical Diagnostic Lines

**Auroral Line Diagnostics ([OIII]λ4363)**
- **Methodology**: Use temperature-sensitive auroral lines to refine AGN classification
- **Advantage**: Better density and temperature determination for NLR; improved AGN/SF separation
- **Challenge**: Auroral lines faint; require high-quality spectroscopy; limit survey applicability

---

### Infrared Coronal Lines

**Highly Ionized Species as AGN Tracers**
- **Lines**: [Ne V], [Mg VII], [Fe VII] (ionization potential > 100 eV)
- **Principle**: Only hard ionizing photons from AGN excite these states; absent in star-forming regions
- **Sensitivity**: Present in NIR spectroscopy of AGN-dominated systems
- **Quantitative Application**: Coronal line detection = definitive AGN identification
- **Limitation**: Weak in low-luminosity systems; require NIR spectroscopy

---

## 8. Summary of Diagnostic Methods and Performance

### Table 1: Diagnostic Methods, Criteria, and Performance Metrics

| Diagnostic Method | Wavelength | Primary Criterion | Completeness | Reliability/Purity | Key Advantages | Key Limitations |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **BPT Optical [NII/Hα vs OIII/Hβ]** | 4400-6600 Å | Kewley et al. (2006) demarcation line | 80-90% (z < 0.3) | 90% (pure regions); 37% (composite region) | Well-established; robust at low-z | Host-galaxy dilution; dust-sensitive; z > 0.4 rest-frame coverage |
| **WISE W1-W2 Color** | 3.4, 4.6 μm | W1 - W2 ≥ 0.8 | 85-95% | 90% (W2 < 15); 70% (W2 > 17) | All-sky; unbiased to obscuration; fast | Weak AGN hosts missed; high-z SF galaxies contaminate |
| **WISE 2D Color-Color** | 3.4-22 μm | W1-W2 vs W2-W3 wedge | 80-85% | 85-92% | Reduced contamination vs W1-W2 alone | W3/W4 affected by SF dust; complex boundaries |
| **Spitzer Mid-IR Spectroscopy** | 5-35 μm | PAH strength; silicate depth; [Ne III]/[Ne II] | 85-90% | 92-95% | Selects obscured AGN; direct ionization diagnostics | Requires spectroscopy (limited samples); extended SF contamination |
| **X-Ray Detection (0.2-10 keV)** | 0.1-10 keV | Hard X-ray excess (> 2 keV) | 70-80% | 85-95% | Penetrates dust; direct accretion indicator | Faint sources low S/N; limited all-sky coverage; needs pointing |
| **SED Fitting (X-CIGALE)** | UV-IR (0.1-24 μm) | AGN bolometric luminosity; torus component | 75-90% | 85-90% | Breaks AGN/host degeneracies; multi-wavelength | Requires extensive photometry (> 10 bands); computational expense |
| **Radio Excess** | 1.4-10 GHz | L_radio / L_radio(SFR) > 1.5-2σ | 80-90% | 80-85% | Dust-free; detects low-luminosity jets | Ambiguous with starburst; requires accurate SFR |
| **NIR Emission-Line Diagnostics** | 1-2.5 μm | [FeII], [CaII], Paschen lines; coronal lines | 70-85% (z < 3) | 90-95% | Less dust-affected than optical; z-extended | Requires NIR spectroscopy; coronal lines faint |
| **Machine Learning (LGBM)** | Multi-wavelength | Trained ensemble classifier | 85-95% | 94.2% (AGN); 92.3% (recall) | Captures feature non-linearities; scalable | Requires unambiguous training set; bias-dependent |
| **Photometric Redshift+Classification** | UV-IR | Multi-band photo-z + SED decomposition | 75-85% | 80-90% | No spectroscopy required; all-sky applicable | AGN/host degeneracies; outlier-prone with few bands |

---

## 9. Major Challenges and Open Problems

### 1. **Host-Galaxy Contamination at High Redshift**
- **Problem**: At z > 0.5, host-galaxy stellar light and star formation dilute AGN optical signatures; optical diagnostics biased toward low-z
- **Current Status**: Affects ~40-50% of z > 1 samples; no universal solution
- **Proposed Solutions**: Multi-wavelength diagnostics; SED fitting; NIR spectroscopy

### 2. **Composite AGN-Starburst Systems**
- **Problem**: Simultaneous AGN accretion and intense star formation occur in mergers; no clean separation in single-wavelength diagnostics
- **Contamination Rate**: ~30-40% of high-z star-forming galaxies likely composites
- **Needed Approaches**: Mandatory multi-wavelength approach; machine learning; high-resolution imaging to spatially resolve AGN and SF

### 3. **Weak AGN in Massive Galaxies**
- **Problem**: AGN contributing < 10% of galaxy luminosity missed by standard diagnostics; yet may be common in quiescent/passive galaxies
- **Prevalence**: ~10% of typical galaxy samples host AGN at borderline detectability
- **Challenge**: SED fitting degeneracies; low signal-to-noise in individual diagnostics
- **Current Status**: Requires joint multi-wavelength constraints; machine learning assists

### 4. **Redshift-Dependent Diagnostic Validity**
- **Problem**: Optical diagnostics require rest-frame optical (z < 0.5 with optical spectroscopy); NIR coverage extends to z ~ 3; but far-IR limited to z ~ 6
- **Consequence**: Different diagnostics apply at different redshifts; comparison samples heterogeneous
- **Mitigation**: Develop consistent photo-z and SED methods across redshift; cross-validate with multi-diagnostic approach

### 5. **AGN Obscuration and Torus Geometry**
- **Problem**: High-obscuration AGN (Type 2, buried AGN) underrepresented in optical and X-ray surveys; bias toward unobscured systems
- **Mid-IR Solution**: WISE and Spitzer select obscured AGN; but weak AGN in this regime still missed
- **Quantitative Issue**: True AGN fraction may be 1.5-2× higher than optical-selected samples suggest

### 6. **Machine Learning Training Set Bias**
- **Problem**: ML classifiers trained on spectroscopic samples biased toward bright, nearby systems; performance on faint, high-z sources unknown
- **Contamination**: Training on BPT-classified samples propagates optical-diagnostic systematics
- **Required Progress**: Diverse, unambiguous training datasets from multiple surveys and diagnostics; explicit bias quantification

### 7. **Low-Luminosity AGN in Dwarf Galaxies**
- **Problem**: Traditional optical diagnostics fail in low-metallicity, low-mass systems; emission-line equivalent widths reduced
- **Current Approach**: Unsupervised ML, radio/X-ray detection, UV lines
- **Challenge**: Minimal training data; sample sizes small; contamination high

---

## 10. State of the Art Summary

As of 2025, the most robust AGN identification combines:

1. **Optical Spectroscopy (where available)**: BPT diagnostics remain gold-standard for z < 0.5; Kewley et al. (2006) demarcation lines standard reference; contamination ~37-40% in intermediate regions
2. **Mid-Infrared Photometry**: WISE W1-W2 ≥ 0.8 criterion provides all-sky AGN selection with 90% reliability; 2D WISE color-color reduces contamination further
3. **X-Ray Observations**: Hard X-ray excess (> 2 keV) confirms AGN; penetrates dust; 85-95% purity but limited sky coverage
4. **Radio Detection**: Radio excess vs. FIR-radio relation identifies radio-mode AGN in quiescent galaxies; complements optical/IR methods
5. **SED Fitting**: Multi-wavelength panchromatic SED fitting (X-CIGALE, ProSpect) breaks AGN/host-galaxy degeneracies; requires > 10 photometric bands
6. **Machine Learning**: LGBM and neural-network classifiers trained on multi-wavelength data achieve > 92% accuracy; scalable to large surveys; requires unambiguous training sets
7. **Multi-Diagnostic Consensus**: Combining 2+ independent methods reduces misclassification by 50-70%; mandatory for ambiguous cases

**Performance Benchmark**:
- High-reliability AGN samples (pure, uncontaminated): > 90% purity achievable with multi-diagnostic approach + SED fitting
- Completeness: 75-85% for unobscured AGN; 50-70% for heavily obscured AGN (requires infrared + radio)
- Composite contamination: ~37% of galaxies in intermediate diagnostic regions; requires individual multi-wavelength assessment

**Emerging Best Practices**:
- Multi-band photometry (> 10 filters) + optical spectroscopy when available
- SED decomposition explicitly accountingfor AGN dust torus
- Machine learning trained on diverse, cross-validated samples
- Explicit contamination quantification for each sample
- Redshift-dependent diagnostic application with validated demarcation lines

---

## References

### Primary Literature Cited

1. Assef, R. J., et al. 2010, ApJ, 713, L127 - Early WISE AGN W1-W2 criterion
2. Assef, R. J., et al. 2013, ApJ, 772, 26 - WISE AGN selection, NDWFS Boötes validation
3. Assef, R. J., et al. 2018, ApJS, 234, 23 - WISE AGN Catalog compilation
4. Baldwin, G. B., Phillips, M. M., Terlevich, R. 1981, PASP, 93, 5 - Foundational BPT diagram
5. Kewley, L. D., Dopita, M. A., Sutherland, R. S., et al. 2001, ApJ, 556, 121 - Theoretical AGN diagnostics
6. Kewley, L. D., Groves, B., Kauffmann, G., Heckman, T. 2006, MNRAS, 372, 961 - Empirical classification scheme; 85,224 SDSS galaxies
7. Thorne, J. E., et al. 2022, MNRAS, 509, 4940 - DEVILS survey SED fitting AGN identification
8. Hot Dust in Panchromatic SED Fitting - Quantifies impact of AGN on stellar mass, SFR, dust attenuation
9. Recent NIR Diagnostics (2023) - Near-infrared emission line diagnostics for AGN (z ∼ 0-3)
10. X-CIGALE (2021-2024) - X-ray to infrared SED fitting; breaks AGN/host degeneracies
11. Radio-AGN Machine Learning (2024-2025) - LGBM classifiers; 94% precision, 92% recall
12. Dwarf AGN Selection (2025) - Unsupervised ML for low-luminosity systems
13. SDSS-IV MaNGA AGN Catalogs (2023-2025) - Optical diagnostic classification of 10,010 galaxies; Type I/II separation

### Key Diagnostic Resources

- AGN Diagnostics Website: [https://sites.google.com/site/agndiagnostics/](https://sites.google.com/site/agndiagnostics/) - Comprehensive compilation of diagnostic diagrams and references
- SDSS Marvin BPT Documentation: Emission-line diagnostic tools for large surveys
- NED IPAC Level 5: Selection of AGN in X-ray waveband; theoretical frameworks

### Survey Datasets Mentioned

- **SDSS/SDSS-IV MaNGA**: 85,000+ emission-line galaxies; optical spectroscopy
- **WISE**: 339 million all-sky infrared sources; W1-W2 mid-IR selection
- **Spitzer Space Telescope**: Mid-infrared spectroscopy (IRS); PAH features
- **COSMOS Field**: Deep multi-wavelength imaging; AGN-SFG classification validation
- **DEVILS Survey**: 217,000 galaxies with spectroscopy; SED fitting AGN fraction
- **LOFAR, VLA**: Radio AGN surveys; radio-excess detection
- **XMM-XXL**: X-ray selected AGN; SED fitting applications

---

## Appendix: Quantitative Diagnostic Thresholds

### BPT Diagnostic Thresholds (Kewley et al. 2006)

**NII Diagnostic**:
- **Star-forming upper boundary**: log([OIII]/Hβ) = 0.61/[log([NII]/Hα) - 0.05] + 1.3
- **AGN lower boundary**: log([OIII]/Hβ) = 0.72/[log([NII]/Hα) - 0.37] + 1.19
- **Composite region**: Between these two curves

**SII Diagnostic**:
- Similar boundaries for [SII]-based classification

**OI Diagnostic**:
- Separates Seyfert 2 from LINER regions

### WISE Color Thresholds

- **W1 - W2 ≥ 0.8**: Conservative AGN selection (90% reliability)
- **W1 - W2 ≥ 0.7**: Higher completeness compromise
- **W1 - W2 ≥ 0.5 or 0.85**: Alternative proposals (lower purity/completeness)

### X-Ray Luminosity Thresholds

- **Hard X-ray excess** (> 2 keV): L_X > 10^42 erg/s typical unobscured AGN
- **Soft X-ray**: Consistent with starburst; L_X < 10^40 erg/s for typical SF galaxies
